title: R in Production
text:
This section explores strategies and best practices for using R in production environments, focusing on reproducibility, deployment, and scalability.



Reproducible research: Creating reproducible analyses and reports
Docker integration: Containerizing R applications for consistent deployment
Performance optimization: Scaling R for larger datasets and computations
Workflow automation: Building data pipelines with targets and drake
Cloud deployment: Running R in cloud environments (AWS, GCP, Azure)
API development: Creating APIs with plumber and FastAPI
Database integration: Efficient database connections and queries





Engineering Production-Grade Shiny Apps - Best practices for production Shiny apps
Efficient R Programming - Performance optimization
targets - Robust reproducible data pipelines
drake - Declarative pipeline toolkit
R Infrastructure - RStudio’s guide to production infrastructure




This section will include examples of deploying R code in production environments and lessons learned.



After working through this section, I should be able to:

Build reproducible R workflows that can run consistently across different environments
Containerize R applications using Docker for deployment
Optimize R code for better performance with large datasets
Create automated data pipelines using targets or drake
Deploy R applications to cloud environments
Develop APIs that expose R functionality to other applications
Establish efficient connections between R and various database systems

title: Advanced R
text:
This section is dedicated to more advanced R programming concepts, based primarily on Hadley Wickham’s Advanced R book. Here, I’ll be exploring R’s language internals, functional programming patterns, metaprogramming, and performance optimization.



Language fundamentals: Understanding R’s unique object and environment systems
Functional programming: Working with functions as first-class objects

Object-oriented programming: Exploring S3, S4, and R6 class systems
Metaprogramming: Manipulating code as data with non-standard evaluation
Performance optimization: Profiling, memory management, and code efficiency
Rcpp integration: Extending R with C++ for performance-critical code





Advanced R, 2nd Edition - Hadley Wickham’s definitive guide
Advanced R Solutions - Companion with exercise answers
The R Inferno - Quirky guide to common R traps





Data Wrangling - Advanced data manipulation techniques




After working through this section, I should be able to:

Understand R’s unique object and environment systems
Apply functional programming patterns to write cleaner, more maintainable code
Implement and use different object-oriented programming systems in R (S3, S4, R6)
Leverage metaprogramming techniques to solve advanced problems
Profile and optimize R code for better performance
Extend R with C++ using Rcpp for performance-critical operations
Debug complex R code more effectively

title: R-Development Garden
text: This is a curated project with the goal of a fully focused deep-dive into learning R. Each section includes resources, practice projects, and learning outcomes.

title: Shiny Apps
text:
This section is dedicated to interactive web applications built with Shiny, R’s powerful web framework for creating data-driven apps and dashboards.



UI fundamentals: Building effective user interfaces with Shiny
Reactivity: Understanding Shiny’s reactive programming model
Performance: Optimizing Shiny apps for speed and scalability
Modules: Creating reusable components with Shiny modules
JavaScript integration: Extending Shiny with custom JavaScript
Deployment: Publishing apps to shinyapps.io, Shiny Server, and RStudio Connect
Authentication: Implementing user authentication in Shiny apps





Mastering Shiny - Hadley Wickham’s comprehensive guide
Engineering Production-Grade Shiny Apps - Deploying Shiny at scale
Shiny Gallery - Examples and inspiration
Interactive Web Data Visualization with Plotly & Shiny - Advanced visualizations
JS4Shiny Field Notes - Add JavaScript to Shiny




This section will showcase the Shiny apps I develop, along with code snippets and lessons learned.



After working through this section, I should be able to:

Build effective user interfaces for data-driven web applications
Implement Shiny’s reactive programming model effectively
Optimize Shiny apps for improved performance and scalability
Create reusable components with Shiny modules
Extend Shiny applications with custom JavaScript functionality
Deploy Shiny applications to various hosting platforms
Implement authentication and authorization in Shiny apps
Create professional dashboards that communicate insights effectively

title: Building Models in R
text:
This section explores statistical modeling, machine learning, and inference techniques in R, covering both classical and modern approaches.



Linear models: Regression, ANOVA, and their extensions
Generalized linear models: Logistic, Poisson regression, and more
Mixed effects models: Analyzing hierarchical and longitudinal data
Bayesian analysis: Using Stan, brms, and Bayesian workflows
Machine learning: Classification, regression, clustering with tidymodels
Deep learning: Neural networks with torch and keras
Model evaluation: Cross-validation, metrics, and model comparison
Interpretable machine learning: Understanding model predictions





Statistical Rethinking (recoded in R) - Bayesian modeling
Regression and Other Stories - Applied regression with R
Hands-on Machine Learning with R - From preprocessing to modeling
Tidy Modeling with R - Using tidymodels framework
Bayes Rules! - Intro Bayesian modeling with R




I’ll document my modeling projects here, including code examples, visualizations, and performance analyses.



After working through this section, I should be able to:

Build and interpret various types of linear and generalized linear models
Implement mixed effects models for hierarchical and longitudinal data
Perform Bayesian analysis using Stan, brms, and related frameworks
Apply machine learning techniques using the tidymodels ecosystem
Implement neural networks and deep learning models in R
Properly evaluate models using cross-validation and appropriate metrics
Interpret model results to derive meaningful insights
Select appropriate modeling approaches for different types of problems

title: R Package Development
text:
This section covers the process of creating, documenting, testing, and sharing R packages. Based primarily on R Packages (2nd Edition) by Hadley Wickham and Jenny Bryan.



Package structure: Understanding the fundamental components of R packages
Documentation: Using roxygen2 for function documentation and vignettes
Testing: Implementing unit tests with testthat
Dependencies: Managing package dependencies efficiently
CRAN submission: Preparing packages for CRAN submission
GitHub integration: Using GitHub for version control and collaboration
Continuous integration: Setting up CI/CD workflows for R packages





R Packages, 2nd Edition - How to write and maintain R packages
Tidyverse Design Guide - Philosophy and patterns for extensibility
rOpenSci Packages Guide - Best practices for scientific packages
Writing R Extensions - Official R manual for package authors




I’ll document my package development journey here, including any packages I create.



After working through this section, I should be able to:

Create well-structured R packages following best practices
Write comprehensive function documentation using roxygen2
Implement effective unit tests to ensure package reliability
Manage package dependencies efficiently
Prepare packages for submission to CRAN
Use GitHub for package version control and collaboration
Set up continuous integration workflows for R packages
Create vignettes and other documentation to help users understand my packages

title: R for Data Science
text:
This section focuses on modern data science workflows in R using the tidyverse collection of packages. Based on the R for Data Science (2nd Edition) book by Hadley Wickham, Mine Çetinkaya-Rundel, and Garrett Grolemund.



Data transformation: Using dplyr for manipulating tabular data
Data visualization: Creating effective graphics with ggplot2
Data import: Reading various file formats into R
Tidy data: Structuring data effectively with tidyr
Exploratory data analysis: Iterative process of visualization and transformation
Communication: Sharing results through reports, dashboards, and visualizations





R for Data Science, 2nd Edition - Modern R workflows using tidyverse
R Programming for Data Science - Introduction from Roger Peng
ModernDive - Statistical inference via data science
Hands-On Programming with R - Learning R through building games




I’ll be adding my practice projects and code examples in this section as I work through the book.



After working through this section, I should be able to:

Transform and manipulate tabular data efficiently using dplyr
Create effective data visualizations with ggplot2
Import data from various file formats into R
Structure data properly using tidy data principles
Conduct thorough exploratory data analysis
Communicate findings through reports and visualizations
Apply data wrangling workflows to real-world datasets
Build reproducible data analysis pipelines
